Not a industry altering idea, but very solid idler. Fairly linear Xp progression without getting too grindy. 
**VERY IMPORTANT!!** This game has a Non-Predatory item shop. Most paid items only offer a minimal xp boost, they operate more as a status symbol than pay to win. As well as most paid items can be traded or sold in the player to player run market.

The game has a pretty chill vibe and a simple design, yet it never feels boring. The balance between grind and chill is handled really well. On top of that, the multiplayer aspect, co-op battles, and trading system are nicely implemented. In these areas, it’s quite a success.

While I understand why everyone compares it to Melvor Idle, I think Idle Clans doesn’t get the credit it deserves. Melvor costs around $25 with its DLCs and doesn’t offer any multiplayer features. Idle Clans, on the other hand, gives you two options — you can either play completely for free and access all paid content through your in-game effort, or unlock it directly. Since it’s not a competitive game, I don’t see any downside to this system; in fact, offering both options is a really nice touch. Plus, earning access to premium content through your own effort feels like a genuine achievement for players.

Aside from that, I find Clans’ balance between grind and chill even better executed than Melvor’s. Definitely an idle game that deserves a chance.

By the way, with a chill or casual playstyle, you can get premium in about a month. Those who play more actively or join a clan can obtain it even sooner.

"Lazy Melvor Idle ripoff" doesn't just come to mind, it's blaring any time you launch the game. 

The idea of online multiplayer for an idle game is novel, but Idle Clans feels like another example that it just doesn't really work. A player-run auctionhouse is unique but not particularly interesting. The game is free to play but you're cut off at the legs if you don't buy premium, and you will loot item after item that clutters up your inventory because their only use is part of premium gameplay.

The biggest complaint - The user experience feels [b]awful[/b]. It's clearly designed for mobile, but every part of the design feels badly executed, and worse on PC. The list of skills is long which works poorly on a landscape-mode-designed game, resulting in a lot of scrolling up and down the list. Interacting with a thing will open a popup that opens a popup that opens a second menu and cancelling out of that menu won't take you back to the screen you were on to begin with. And [b]everything[/b] wants to open in a popup. The inventory is a mess and lacks the bank tabs of Melvor to at least somewhat organize it, so swapping equipment sets will haphazardly throw your gear back to the top of your inventory every time.

Skills are barebones, and feel pointless beyond completing daily quests. Chop wood with lumberjacking so you can use the wood to turn it into planks. What do you use the planks for? Nothing.

Combat doesn't feel interesting - They've tried to mimic Runescape (And by extension, Melvor)'s melee/archery/magic system, but runes and element types have been stripped of the magic system which makes it flavorless, and rather than the rock-paper-scissors attack type circle, enemies just have a weakness to a particular attack type - of which there are like, eight, because melee weapons all have different attack types. So you have crushing, slashing, stabbing, and pounding, but they do nothing other than ensure that you need four extra inventory slots to carry all the weapons you don't need.

Loot from any source that isn't a direct "X seconds => 1 item" system is heavily RNG based, turning time investment into a gamble to see if you get the thing you want. The idea of online multiplayer for an idle game is novel, but Idle Clans feels like another example that it just doesn't really work. A player-run auctionhouse is unique but not particularly interesting. The game is free to play but you're cut off at the legs if you don't buy premium, and you will loot item after item that clutters up your inventory because their only use is part of premium gameplay.

The biggest complaint - The user experience feels [b]awful[/b]. It's clearly designed for mobile, but every part of the design feels badly executed, and worse on PC. The list of skills is long which works poorly on a landscape-mode-designed game, resulting in a lot of scrolling up and down the list. Interacting with a thing will open a popup that opens a popup that opens a second menu and cancelling out of that menu won't take you back to the screen you were on to begin with. And [b]everything[/b] wants to open in a popup. The inventory is a mess and lacks the bank tabs of Melvor to at least somewhat organize it, so swapping equipment sets will haphazardly throw your gear back to the top of your inventory every time.

Skills are barebones, and feel pointless beyond completing daily quests. Chop wood with lumberjacking so you can use the wood to turn it into planks. What do you use the planks for? Nothing.

Combat doesn't feel interesting - They've tried to mimic Runescape (And by extension, Melvor)'s melee/archery/magic system, but runes and element types have been stripped of the magic system which makes it flavorless, and rather than the rock-paper-scissors attack type circle, enemies just have a weakness to a particular attack type - of which there are like, eight, because melee weapons all have different attack types. So you have crushing, slashing, stabbing, and pounding, but they do nothing other than ensure that you need four extra inventory slots to carry all the weapons you don't need.

Loot from any source that isn't a direct "X seconds => 1 item" system is heavily RNG based, turning time investment into a gamble to see if you get the thing you want. While RNG in a game like this isn't uncommon, the actual drop rates combined with everything else turns it into a slog. I spent so much time grinding the singular creature that drops green leather (tier 3 leather), a mob that I was already vastly overleveled for, to get enough to make myself a set of armor that by the time I had gotten the 6 pieces needed, I had already outleveled the gear as well and needed red leather (tier 4).
